title: SeaWorld barred from breeding animals in captivity
text:
SeaWorld barred from breeding animals in captivity 
Entertainment Industry News.Net : Sunday 11th October, 2015 
SAN DIEGO, California - Californian officials have barred SeaWorld from breeding animals in captivity in the state, calling into question the future viability of the park's popular orca whale attraction. 
The California Coastal Commission delivered its ruling after the San Diego-based aquarium submitted a request to build new tanks for its killer whales. 
SeaWorld said in a statement that it was "disappointed" with Thursday's ruling, but that it would push ahead with the building of the two new tanks for viewing and research. 
"Breeding is a natural, fundamental and important part of an animal's life and depriving a social animal of the right to reproduce is inhumane", SeaWorld San Diego Park President John Reilly said in the statement. 
The building of the two tanks have been approved "under a condition that would prohibit captive breeding, artificial insemination, and the sale, trade or transfer of any animal in captivity." 
The California Coastal Commission delivered it ruling after receiving more than 120,000 emails from the public about the proposed expansion, mostly from those opposing the project, according to commission spokeswoman Noaki Schwartz. 
Only SeaWorld's San Diego business will be affected, not its locations in Florida or Texas. 
The People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) welcomed the ruling, and said this would effectively end the orca whale exhibit in California. 
The ruling "ensures that no more orcas will be condemned to a nonlife of loneliness, deprivation and misery" the group said in a statement. 
SeaWorld in recent years has been heavily criticised over its handling of killer whales, particularly after the release of the controversial 2013 documentary Blackfish, which specifically criticized the company's orca programme. 
Blackfish is an alleged expose that claims whales in captivity become bored in their sterile environment, which makes them aggressive towards their human trainers, using the deaths of several employees, many of them under extremely grim circumstances, as evidence. 
SeaWorld has called the film "false and misleading". More Entertainment Industry News
